risks.title: Complex Local Setup and High Hardware Requirements Limit Mainstream Adoption
risks.description: The project's reliance on local AI processing and dedicated server hardware, such as a Mac mini or similar, presents a significant barrier to entry for mainstream users. The specified hardware requirements, particularly for vision models (e.g., Qwen2.5-VL needing 24GB VRAM and 32GB system RAM), will deter a broader audience accustomed to simple, cloud-based solutions.

evidence.quote: Niche vs. Mainstream Appeal: System complexity and local server requirement might limit initial appeal.

The 7B/8B Qwen2.5-VL models require approximately 24GB VRAM and 32GB system RAM. The 32B version would need a Mac M-series with at least 32GB RAM (64GB recommended) and over 60GB of storage. These are significant hardware considerations for local deployment.

mitigation: Optimize models for lower-end hardware and provide clear, simple setup guides.
Offer a tiered approach with a cloud AI processing service for users without high-end local hardware (with user consent and data anonymization where appropriate).
Partner with OEMs to offer pre-configured, optimized hardware solutions.
Emphasize the long-term cost benefits of local processing vs. recurring cloud fees.

risks.title: Rapidly Evolving AI Landscape and Big Tech Competition
risks.description: The AI industry is evolving at an unprecedented pace. Large technology companies, with vast resources, could quickly develop and integrate similar privacy-focused or local-first features, potentially eroding PrivateAI's competitive advantage before it gains significant market share.

evidence.quote: Rapidly Evolving AI Landscape & Big Tech Competition: Major tech companies could release similar features. This is a significant concern.
Sustainability of 'Local-First' Advantage: OS vendors might improve on-device privacy features.

mitigation: Continuously innovate on core privacy-by-design principles, extensibility, and community-driven development that Big Tech struggles to replicate.
Focus on delivering truly deeper personalization and user control enabled by local access that generic cloud solutions cannot match.
Build a strong developer ecosystem through open-source contributions and a plugin marketplace.

risks.title: Inherent Security Risks of Plugin Ecosystem and Local Code Execution
risks.description: The initial idea of allowing local compilation and execution of Rust source code for plugins carries extremely high security risks. Without robust sandboxing, malicious plugins could gain full access to user data and system resources. Even with proposed WASM sandboxing, ensuring the security of third-party plugins in an open-source model is a significant challenge.

evidence.quote: Initial (High-Risk) Idea for Rust Plugins: Download Rust source code, compile it locally on the user's machine, and then run the resulting binary. This approach is strongly advised against due to major security risks and usability hurdles.
Plugin System Security: Local compilation of Rust source is high-risk. Mitigation: Adopt WASM for sandboxed execution or, at least, signed pre-compiled binaries with a strong permission model.

mitigation: Strictly enforce WebAssembly (WASM) for all plugins, providing a sandboxed execution environment.
Implement a robust permission model for plugins, requiring explicit user consent for resource access (filesystem, network).
Establish a clear distinction between audited/official plugins and unaudited third-party plugins, with warnings for users.
Develop a transparent vulnerability disclosure and rapid patching process.

risks.title: Challenges in Monetization for a Local-First, Open-Source Product
risks.description: Monetizing an open-source, local-first product can be challenging. Users who prioritize data sovereignty may also be averse to subscription models for what they perceive as locally-owned software. The reliance on 'convenience' features as a primary differentiator for paid tiers might not be enough to attract and retain sufficient paying users.

evidence.quote: Monetization: Justifying subscriptions for local-first software; funding open-source. Mitigation: Diversified revenue streams (see Business Model).
Paid 'Convenience' Version (e.g., $25/month for individuals): This tier will provide features that simplify setup, offer a more polished user experience, and grant access to managed services.

mitigation: Clearly articulate the value proposition of paid 'convenience' features and managed services (e.g., seamless updates, mobile apps, curated marketplace, secure remote access).
Explore a freemium model with truly compelling premium features that go beyond convenience and offer enhanced functionality.
Leverage professional services and enterprise solutions as significant revenue drivers.
Actively engage the community to understand willingness to pay and desired premium features.

risks.title: Limitations in Mobile Data Collection and Integration
risks.description: Operating system restrictions on mobile devices (iOS and Android) severely limit the ability to conduct continuous background screen monitoring and detailed UI event capture, which are core data sources for the desktop vision. This significantly impedes the vision of a 'comprehensive digital footprint' across all user devices.

evidence.quote: Initial Scope is Limited: Full, continuous background screen monitoring and detailed UI event capture (as envisioned for desktops) are highly challenging and likely infeasible on non-jailbroken iOS and Android devices due to strict OS-level restrictions on background activity and data access.
Mobile data collection (continuous background screen monitoring, detailed UI events) is highly challenging and likely infeasible on non-jailbroken iOS/Android.

mitigation: Redefine the role of the mobile client to focus on user-initiated inputs (Share Button, cloud folder monitoring) and querying the home server.
Explore app-specific integrations and notification capture for contextual snippets, with explicit user permission.
Prioritize desktop functionality for the MVP and defer complex mobile integration to later phases, or manage scope by focusing on mobile as a 'remote control' rather than a data source.
Clearly communicate mobile limitations to users to manage expectations.
